@forgivenes42 you don't know what you're missing :)

@Gullshunter While other phenomenons are possible, the reality is the direction the wheel is turned will be the opposite of where the bike will fall too if the bike is straight up. In a turn you're falling, but the resistance of turning into the turn is keeping you up.
@Gullshunter No because thin wheels have no traction and it will just slip and fall.

@JacktheSmack wonder if it does work with a really really thin wheel. I mean almost 2 dimentionnal. Also, you'r thing seems logic, but i'm pretty sure that other phenomenes are also responsible for this.

@Gullshunter Same concept, but the wheel will turn to the side the bike is leaning on its own because of how bikes are designed. You could design a bike that would be hard to balance on, and would fall quickly on its own.
dude that looked so cool

@JacktheSmack can you now explain it if we are not on the bike. ex:ghost driver? when we spin the bike, then get out. It will take more time to fall than if there was no inititial movement even if you're not there to do those small movement. Try it, you will see

@Gullshunter Counter balance. If you turn the wheel to the right, the bike leans left, and if you turn the wheel to the left, the bike leans right. When you've biked enough you do these small movements without thinking. This is why losing front wheel traction can result in a fall, but rear wheel traction loss will only drift the bike.
